abstract: Google.org, the search company’s struggling philanthropic arm, was revamped this year, and charitable grant-making was added. It gave away $115 million, $40 million of which went to its pet causes of math and science education; fighting slavery and trafficking; using technology to solve problems; and educating girls.
snippet: Google.org, the search company’s struggling philanthropic arm, was revamped this year, and charitable grant-making was added. It gave away $115 million, $40 million of which went to its pet causes of math and science education; fighting slavery an...
lead_paragraph: Google.org, the search giant’s philanthropic arm, has struggled, but Google continues to give away money.

headline.main: Google Celebrates the Season by Promoting Its Charitable Grants

abstract: On Wednesday, Nokia announced the first step in its comeback in the United States with its first smartphone based on Microsoft’s Windows Phone operating system. Anyone hoping for Nokia to market its return with guns cocked and aimed at Apple and Google is likely to be disappointed, though.
snippet: On Wednesday, Nokia announced the first step in its comeback in the United States with its first smartphone based on Microsoft’s Windows Phone operating system. Anyone hoping for Nokia to market its return with guns cocked and aimed at Apple and G...
lead_paragraph: The past few years have not been kind to Nokia in the cellphone market, especially in the United States where homegrown iPhones and Android handsets crowded out the venerable Finnish handset maker.

headline.main: Nokia Courts Smartphone Newbies in U.S. Return

abstract: The House and the Senate are looking to cut off oxygen for sites that offer free copies of entertainment by taking aim at search engines like Google and Yahoo that allow the pirates to function.
snippet: The House and the Senate are looking to cut off oxygen for sites that offer free copies of entertainment by taking aim at search engines like Google and Yahoo that allow the pirates to function.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Type “download movies for free” into Google, and up pops links to sites like the Pirate Bay, directing users to free copies of just about any entertainment   — the latest “Twilight” installment, this week’s episode of “Whitney,” the complete recordings of the Red Hot Chili Peppers.

abstract: Data gathered by Clearspring, a provider of sharing tools and analytics, shows that people like to share on Wednesdays. They like to share on Facebook. They like to share on the iPad. And they shared a lot about Osama bin Laden.
snippet: Data gathered by Clearspring, a provider of sharing tools and analytics, shows that people like to share on Wednesdays. They like to share on Facebook. They like to share on the iPad. And they shared a lot about Osama bin Laden.
lead_paragraph: It’s Wednesday. That means it is the most popular day for users to share on the Web.

headline.main: Online Sharing: The How, What and When of 2011
